# File System API

**Secure context:** This feature is available only in [secure contexts](/en-US/docs/Web/Security/Secure_Contexts) (HTTPS), in some or all [supporting browsers](#browser_compatibility).

**Note:** This feature is available in [Web Workers](/en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_Workers_API).

The **File System API** — with extensions provided via the [**File System Access API**](https://wicg.github.io/file-system-access/) to access files on the device file system — allows read, write and file management capabilities.

See [Relationship to other file-related APIs](/en-US/docs/Web/API/File_API#relationship_to_other_file-related_apis) for a comparison between this API, the [File and Directory Entries API](/en-US/docs/Web/API/File_and_Directory_Entries_API), and the [File API](/en-US/docs/Web/API/File_API).

## In this article

* [Concepts and Usage](#concepts_and_usage)
* [Interfaces](#interfaces)
* [Examples](#examples)
* [Specifications](#specifications)
* [Browser compatibility](#browser_compatibility)
* [See also](#see_also)

## [Concepts and Usage](#concepts_and_usage)

This API allows interaction with files on a user's local device, or on a user-accessible network file system. Core functionality of this API includes reading files, writing or saving files, and access to directory structure.

Most of the interaction with files and directories is accomplished through handles. A parent [`FileSystemHandle`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemHandle) class helps define two child classes: [`FileSystemFileHandle`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemFileHandle) and [`FileSystemDirectoryHandle`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemDirectoryHandle), for files and directories respectively.

The handles represent a file or directory on the user's system. You can first gain access to them by showing the user a file or directory picker using methods such as [`window.showOpenFilePicker()`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/showOpenFilePicker) and [`window.showDirectoryPicker()`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/showDirectoryPicker). Once these are called, the file picker presents itself and the user selects either a file or directory. Once this happens successfully, a handle is returned.

You can also gain access to file handles via:

* The [`DataTransferItem.getAsFileSystemHandle()`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/DataTransferItem/getAsFileSystemHandle) method of the [HTML Drag and Drop API](/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTML_Drag_and_Drop_API).
* The [File Handling API](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/capabilities/web-apis/file-handling).

Each handle provides its own functionality and there are a few differences depending on which one you are using (see the [interfaces](#interfaces) section for specific details). You then can access file data, or information (including children) of the directory selected. This API opens up potential functionality the web has been lacking. Still, security has been of utmost concern when designing the API, and access to file/directory data is disallowed unless the user specifically permits it (note that this is not the case with the [Origin private file system](#origin_private_file_system), because it is not visible to the user).

**Note:** The different exceptions that can be thrown when using the features of this API are listed on relevant pages as defined in the spec. However, the situation is made more complex by the interaction of the API and the underlying operating system. A proposal has been made to [list the error mappings in the spec](https://github.com/whatwg/fs/issues/57), which includes useful related information.

**Note:** Objects based on [`FileSystemHandle`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemHandle) can also be serialized into an [IndexedDB](/en-US/docs/Web/API/IndexedDB_API "IndexedDB") database instance, or transferred via [`postMessage()`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/postMessage "postMessage()").

### [Origin private file system](#origin_private_file_system)

The origin private file system (OPFS) is a storage endpoint provided as part of the File System API, which is private to the origin of the page and not visible to the user like the regular file system. It provides access to a special kind of file that is highly optimized for performance and offers in-place write access to its content.

The following are some possible use cases:

* Apps with persistent uploader

  * When a file or directory is selected for upload, you can copy the file into a local sandbox and upload a chunk at a time.
  * The app can restart uploads after an interruption, such as the browser being closed or crashing, connectivity getting interrupted, or the computer getting shut down.

* Video game or other apps with lots of media assets

  * The app downloads one or several large tarballs and expands them locally into a directory structure.
  * The app pre-fetches assets in the background, so the user can go to the next task or game level without waiting for a download.

* Audio or photo editor with offline access or local cache (great for performance and speed)

  * The app can write to files in place (for example, overwriting just the ID3/EXIF tags and not the entire file).

* Offline video viewer

  * The app can download large files (>1GB) for later viewing.
  * The app can access partially downloaded files (so that you can watch the first chapter of your DVD, even if the app is still downloading the rest of the content or if the app didn't complete the download because you had to run to catch a train).

* Offline web mail client

  * The client downloads attachments and stores them locally.
  * The client caches attachments for later upload.

Read our [Origin private file system](/en-US/docs/Web/API/File_System_API/Origin_private_file_system) for instructions on how to use it.

### [Saving files](#saving_files)

* In the case of the asynchronous handles, use the [`FileSystemWritableFileStream`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemWritableFileStream) interface. Once the data you'd like to save is in a format of [`Blob`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/Blob), [`String`](/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String) object, string literal or [`buffer`](/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/ArrayBuffer), you can open a stream and save the data to a file. This can be the existing file or a new file.
* In the case of the synchronous [`FileSystemSyncAccessHandle`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemSyncAccessHandle), you write changes to a file using the [`write()`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemSyncAccessHandle/write "write()") method. You can optionally also call [`flush()`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemSyncAccessHandle/flush "flush()") if you need the changes committed to disk at a specific time (otherwise you can leave the underlying operating system to handle this when it sees fit, which should be OK in most cases).

## [Interfaces](#interfaces)

[`FileSystemChangeRecord`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemChangeRecord) <abbr>Experimental</abbr>

Contains details of a single change observed by a [`FileSystemObserver`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemObserver).

[`FileSystemHandle`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemHandle)

An object which represents a file or directory entry. Multiple handles can represent the same entry. For the most part you do not work with `FileSystemHandle` directly but rather its child interfaces [`FileSystemFileHandle`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemFileHandle) and [`FileSystemDirectoryHandle`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemDirectoryHandle).

[`FileSystemFileHandle`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemFileHandle)

Provides a handle to a file system entry.

[`FileSystemDirectoryHandle`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemDirectoryHandle)

Provides a handle to a file system directory.

[`FileSystemObserver`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemObserver) <abbr>Experimental</abbr>

Provides a mechanism to observe changes to selected files or directories.

[`FileSystemSyncAccessHandle`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemSyncAccessHandle)

Provides a synchronous handle to a file system entry, which operates in-place on a single file on disk. The synchronous nature of the file reads and writes allows for higher performance for critical methods in contexts where asynchronous operations come with high overhead, e.g., [WebAssembly](/en-US/docs/WebAssembly). This class is only accessible inside dedicated [Web Workers](/en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_Workers_API) for files within the [origin private file system](#origin_private_file_system).

[`FileSystemWritableFileStream`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemWritableFileStream)

A [`WritableStream`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/WritableStream) object with additional convenience methods, which operates on a single file on disk.

### [Extensions to other interfaces](#extensions_to_other_interfaces)

[`Window.showDirectoryPicker()`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/showDirectoryPicker)

Displays a directory picker which allows the user to select a directory.

[`Window.showOpenFilePicker()`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/showOpenFilePicker)

Shows a file picker that allows a user to select a file or multiple files.

[`Window.showSaveFilePicker()`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/showSaveFilePicker)

Shows a file picker that allows a user to save a file.

[`DataTransferItem.getAsFileSystemHandle()`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/DataTransferItem/getAsFileSystemHandle)

Returns a [`Promise`](/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Promise) that fulfills with a [`FileSystemFileHandle`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemFileHandle) if the dragged item is a file, or fulfills with a [`FileSystemDirectoryHandle`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemDirectoryHandle) if the dragged item is a directory.

[`StorageManager.getDirectory()`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/StorageManager/getDirectory)

Used to obtain a reference to a [`FileSystemDirectoryHandle`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemDirectoryHandle) object allowing access to a directory and its contents, stored in the [origin private file system](/en-US/docs/Web/API/File_System_API/Origin_private_file_system). Returns a [`Promise`](/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Promise) that fulfills with a [`FileSystemDirectoryHandle`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemDirectoryHandle) object.

## [Examples](#examples)
<?>

### [Accessing files](#accessing_files)

The below code allows the user to choose a file from the file picker.

js

```
async function getFile() {
  // Open file picker and destructure the result the first handle
  const [fileHandle] = await window.showOpenFilePicker();
  const file = await fileHandle.getFile();
  return file;
}
```

The following asynchronous function presents a file picker and once a file is chosen, uses the `getFile()` method to retrieve the contents.

js

```
const pickerOpts = {
  types: [
    {
      description: "Images",
      accept: {
        "image/*": [".png", ".gif", ".jpeg", ".jpg"],
      },
    },
  ],
  excludeAcceptAllOption: true,
  multiple: false,
};

async function getTheFile() {
  // Open file picker and destructure the result the first handle
  const [fileHandle] = await window.showOpenFilePicker(pickerOpts);

  // get file contents
  const fileData = await fileHandle.getFile();
}
```

### [Accessing directories](#accessing_directories)

The following example returns a directory handle with the specified name. If the directory does not exist, it is created.

js

```
const dirName = "directoryToGetName";

// assuming we have a directory handle: 'currentDirHandle'
const subDir = currentDirHandle.getDirectoryHandle(dirName, { create: true });
```

The following asynchronous function uses `resolve()` to find the path to a chosen file, relative to a specified directory handle.

js

```
async function returnPathDirectories(directoryHandle) {
  // Get a file handle by showing a file picker:
  const [handle] = await self.showOpenFilePicker();
  if (!handle) {
    // User cancelled, or otherwise failed to open a file.
    return;
  }

  // Check if handle exists inside our directory handle
  const relativePaths = await directoryHandle.resolve(handle);

  if (relativePaths === null) {
    // Not inside directory handle
  } else {
    // relativePaths is an array of names, giving the relative path

    for (const name of relativePaths) {
      // log each entry
      console.log(name);
    }
  }
}
```

### [Writing to files](#writing_to_files)

The following asynchronous function opens the save file picker, which returns a [`FileSystemFileHandle`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemFileHandle) once a file is selected. A writable stream is then created using the [`FileSystemFileHandle.createWritable()`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemFileHandle/createWritable) method.

A user defined [`Blob`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/Blob) is then written to the stream which is subsequently closed.

js

```
async function saveFile() {
  // create a new handle
  const newHandle = await window.showSaveFilePicker();

  // create a FileSystemWritableFileStream to write to
  const writableStream = await newHandle.createWritable();

  // write our file
  await writableStream.write(imgBlob);

  // close the file and write the contents to disk.
  await writableStream.close();
}
```

The following show different examples of options that can be passed into the `write()` method.

js

```
// just pass in the data (no options)
writableStream.write(data);

// writes the data to the stream from the determined position
writableStream.write({ type: "write", position, data });

// updates the current file cursor offset to the position specified
writableStream.write({ type: "seek", position });

// resizes the file to be size bytes long
writableStream.write({ type: "truncate", size });
```

### [Synchronously reading and writing files in OPFS](#synchronously_reading_and_writing_files_in_opfs)

This example synchronously reads and writes a file to the [origin private file system](#origin_private_file_system).

The following asynchronous event handler function is contained inside a Web Worker. On receiving a message from the main thread it:

* Creates a synchronous file access handle.
* Gets the size of the file and creates an [`ArrayBuffer`](/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/ArrayBuffer) to contain it.
* Reads the file contents into the buffer.
* Encodes the message and writes it to the end of the file.
* Persists the changes to disk and closes the access handle.

js

```
onmessage = async (e) => {
  // retrieve message sent to work from main script
  const message = e.data;

  // Get handle to draft file in OPFS
  const root = await navigator.storage.getDirectory();
  const draftHandle = await root.getFileHandle("draft.txt", { create: true });
  // Get sync access handle
  const accessHandle = await draftHandle.createSyncAccessHandle();

  // Get size of the file.
  const fileSize = accessHandle.getSize();
  // Read file content to a buffer.
  const buffer = new DataView(new ArrayBuffer(fileSize));
  const readBuffer = accessHandle.read(buffer, { at: 0 });

  // Write the message to the end of the file.
  const encoder = new TextEncoder();
  const encodedMessage = encoder.encode(message);
  const writeBuffer = accessHandle.write(encodedMessage, { at: readBuffer });

  // Persist changes to disk.
  accessHandle.flush();

  // Always close FileSystemSyncAccessHandle if done.
  accessHandle.close();
};
```

**Note:** In earlier versions of the spec, [`close()`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemSyncAccessHandle/close "close()"), [`flush()`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemSyncAccessHandle/flush "flush()"), [`getSize()`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemSyncAccessHandle/getSize "getSize()"), and [`truncate()`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemSyncAccessHandle/truncate "truncate()") were unergonomically specified as asynchronous methods. This has now been [amended](https://github.com/whatwg/fs/issues/7), but some browsers still support the asynchronous versions.

[showDirectoryPicker()](/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/showDirectoryPicker) # Window: showDirectoryPicker() method
Limited availability This feature is not Baseline because it does not work in some of the most widely-used browsers. * [Learn more](/en-US/docs/Glossary/Baseline/Compatibility) * [See full compatibility](#browser_compatibility) * [Report feedback](https://survey.alchemer.com/s3/7634825/MDN-baseline-feedback?page=%2Fen-US%2Fdocs%2FWeb%2FAPI%2FWindow%2FshowDirectoryPicker&level=not)
**Secure context:** This feature is available only in [secure contexts](/en-US/docs/Web/Security/Secure_Contexts) (HTTPS), in some or all [supporting browsers](#browser_compatibility). **Experimental:** **This is an [experimental technology](/en-US/docs/MDN/Writing_guidelines/Experimental_deprecated_obsolete#experimental)** Check the [Browser compatibility table](#browser_compatibility) carefully before using this in production. The **`showDirectoryPicker()`** method of the [`Window`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window) interface displays a directory picker which allows the user to select a directory. ## In this article * [Syntax](#syntax) * [Security](#security) * [Examples](#examples) * [Specifications](#specifications) * [Browser compatibility](#browser_compatibility) * [See also](#see_also) ## [Syntax](#syntax) js ``` showDirectoryPicker() showDirectoryPicker(options) ``` ### [Parameters](#parameters) [`options` Optional](#options) An object containing options, which are as follows: [`id` Optional](#id) By specifying an ID, the browser can remember different directories for different IDs. If the same ID is used for another picker, the picker opens in the same directory. [`mode` Optional](#mode) A string that defaults to `"read"` for read-only access or `"readwrite"` for read and write access to the directory. [`startIn` Optional](#startin) A [`FileSystemHandle`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemHandle) or a well known directory (`"desktop"`, `"documents"`, `"downloads"`, `"music"`, `"pictures"`, or `"videos"`) to open the dialog in. ### [Return value](#return_value) A [`Promise`](/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Promise) whose fulfillment handler receives a [`FileSystemDirectoryHandle`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemDirectoryHandle) object. ### [Exceptions](#exceptions) `AbortError` [`DOMException`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/DOMException) Thrown if the user dismisses the prompt without making a selection, or if the user agent deems the selected directory to be too sensitive or dangerous, or if the [`PermissionStatus.state`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/PermissionStatus/state) for the selected directory is not `"granted"` in the specified `mode`. `SecurityError` [`DOMException`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/DOMException) Thrown if the call was blocked by the [same-origin policy](/en-US/docs/Web/Security/Same-origin_policy) or it was not called via a user interaction such as a button press. ## [Security](#security) [Transient user activation](/en-US/docs/Web/Security/User_activation) is required. The user has to interact with the page or a UI element in order for this feature to work. ## [Examples](#examples) This asynchronous function shows a directory picker and returns a [`FileSystemDirectoryHandle`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemDirectoryHandle) once selected. js ``` async function getDir() { const dirHandle = await window.showDirectoryPicker(); // run code for dirHandle } ``` ## [Specifications](#specifications) |Specification| |---| |[File System Access

[Web](/en-US/docs/Web) 2. [Web APIs](/en-US/docs/Web/API) 3. [SubtleCrypto](/en-US/docs/Web/API/SubtleCrypto) 4. [digest()](/en-US/docs/Web/API/SubtleCrypto/digest) # SubtleCrypto: digest() method
Baseline Widely available This feature is well established and works across many devices and browser versions. It’s been available across browsers since ⁨January 2020⁩. * [Learn more](/en-US/docs/Glossary/Baseline/Compatibility) * [See full compatibility](#browser_compatibility) * [Report feedback](https://survey.alchemer.com/s3/7634825/MDN-baseline-feedback?page=%2Fen-US%2Fdocs%2FWeb%2FAPI%2FSubtleCrypto%2Fdigest&level=high)
**Secure context:** This feature is available only in [secure contexts](/en-US/docs/Web/Security/Secure_Contexts) (HTTPS), in some or all [supporting browsers](#browser_compatibility). **Note:** This feature is available in [Web Workers](/en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_Workers_API). The **`digest()`** method of the [`SubtleCrypto`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/SubtleCrypto) interface generates a *digest* of the given data, using the specified [hash function](/en-US/docs/Glossary/Hash_function). A digest is a short fixed-length value derived from some variable-length input. Cryptographic digests should exhibit collision-resistance, meaning that it's hard to come up with two different inputs that have the same digest value. It takes as its arguments an identifier for the digest algorithm to use and the data to digest. It returns a [`Promise`](/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Promise) which will be fulfilled with the digest. Note that this API does not support streaming input: you must read the entire input into memory before passing it into the digest function. ## In this article * [Syntax](#syntax) * [Supported algorithms](#supported_algorithms) * [Examples](#examples) * [Specifications](#specifications) * [Browser compatibility](#browser_compatibility) * [See also](#see_also) ## [Syntax](#syntax) js ``` digest(algorithm, data) ``` ### [Parameters](#parameters) [`algorithm`](#algorithm) This may be a string or an object with a single property `name` that is a string. The string names the hash function to use. Supported values are: * `"SHA-1"` (but don't use this in cryptographic applications) * `"SHA-256"` * `"SHA-384"` * `"SHA-512"`. [`data`](#data) An [`ArrayBuffer`](/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/ArrayBuffer), a [`TypedArray`](/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/TypedArray) or a [`DataView`](/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/DataView) object containing the data to be digested. ### [Return value](#return_value) A [`Promise`](/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Promise) that fulfills with an [`ArrayBuffer`](/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/ArrayBuffer) containing the digest. ## [Supported algorithms](#supported_algorithms) Digest algorithms, also known as [hash functions](/en-US/docs/Glossary/Hash_function), transform an arbitrarily large block of data into a fixed-size output, usually much shorter than the input. They have a variety of applications in cryptography. ||||| |---|---|---|---| |Algorithm|Output length (bits)|Block size (bits)|Specification| |SHA-1|160|512|[FIPS 180-4](https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/FIPS/NIST.FIPS.180-4.pdf), section 6.1| |SHA-256|256|512|[FIPS 180-4](https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/FIPS/NIST.FIPS.180-4.pdf), section 6.2| |SHA-384|384|1024|[FIPS 180-4](https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/FIPS/NIST.FIPS.180-4.pdf), section 6.5| |SHA-512|512|1024|[FIPS 180-4](https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/FIPS/NIST.FIPS.180-4.pdf), section 6.4| **Warning:** SHA-1 is now considered vulnerable and should not be used for cryptographic applications. **Note:** If you are looking here for how to create a keyed-hash message authentication code ([HMAC](/en-US/docs/Glossary/HMAC)), you need to use the [SubtleCrypto.sign()](/en-US/docs/Web/API/SubtleCrypto/sign#hmac) instead. ## [Examples](#examples) For more examples of using the `digest()` API, see [Non-cryptographic uses of SubtleCrypto](/en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_Crypto_API/Non-cryptographic_uses_of_subtle_crypto). ### [Basic example](#basic_example) This example encodes a message, then calculates its SHA-256 digest and logs the digest length: js ``` const text = "An obscure body in the S-K System, your majesty. The inhabitants refer to it as the planet Earth."; async function digestMessage(message) { const encoder = new TextEncoder(); const data = encoder.encode(message); const hash = await window.crypto.subtle.digest("SHA-256", data); return hash; } digestMessage(text).then((digestBuffer) => console.log(digestBuffer.byteLength), ); ``` ### [Converting a digest to a hex string](#converting_a_digest_to_a_hex_string) The digest is returned as an `ArrayBuffer`, but for comparison and display digests are often represented as hex strings. This example calculates a digest, then converts the `ArrayBuffer` to a hex string: js ``` const text = "An obscure body in the S-K System, your majesty. The inhabitants refer to it as the planet Earth."; async function digestMessage(message) { const msgUint8 = new TextEncoder().encode(message); // encode as (utf-8) Uint8Array const hashBuffer = await window.crypto.subtle.digest("SHA-256", msgUint8); // hash the message const hashArray = Array.from(new Uint8Array(hashBuffer)); // convert buffer to byte array const hashHex = hashArray .map((b) => b.toString(16).padStart(2, "0")) .join(""); // convert bytes to hex string return hashHex; } digestMessage(text).then((digestHex) => console.log(digestHex)); ``` ## [Specifications](#specifications) |Specification| |---| |[Web Cryptography Level 2

[getDirectory()](/en-US/docs/Web/API/StorageManager/getDirectory) # StorageManager: getDirectory() method
Baseline 2023 Newly available Since ⁨March 2023⁩, this feature works across the latest devices and browser versions. This feature might not work in older devices or browsers. * [Learn more](/en-US/docs/Glossary/Baseline/Compatibility) * [See full compatibility](#browser_compatibility) * [Report feedback](https://survey.alchemer.com/s3/7634825/MDN-baseline-feedback?page=%2Fen-US%2Fdocs%2FWeb%2FAPI%2FStorageManager%2FgetDirectory&level=low)
**Secure context:** This feature is available only in [secure contexts](/en-US/docs/Web/Security/Secure_Contexts) (HTTPS), in some or all [supporting browsers](#browser_compatibility). **Note:** This feature is available in [Web Workers](/en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_Workers_API). The **`getDirectory()`** method of the [`StorageManager`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/StorageManager) interface is used to obtain a reference to a [`FileSystemDirectoryHandle`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemDirectoryHandle) object allowing access to a directory and its contents, stored in the [origin private file system](/en-US/docs/Web/API/File_System_API/Origin_private_file_system) (OPFS). ## In this article * [Syntax](#syntax) * [Examples](#examples) * [Specifications](#specifications) * [Browser compatibility](#browser_compatibility) * [See also](#see_also) ## [Syntax](#syntax) js ``` getDirectory() ``` ### [Parameters](#parameters) None. ### [Return value](#return_value) A [`Promise`](/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Promise) that fulfills with a [`FileSystemDirectoryHandle`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemDirectoryHandle) object. ### [Exceptions](#exceptions) `SecurityError` [`DOMException`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/DOMException) Thrown if the browser is not able to map the requested directory to the local OPFS, for example due to storage or memory constraints. Also thrown in some browsers if `getDirectory()` is called in private browsing mode. `UnknownError` [`DOMException`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/DOMException) Thrown in some browsers if `getDirectory()` is called in private browsing mode. ## [Examples](#examples) The following asynchronous event handler function is contained inside a Web Worker. On receiving a message from the main thread it: 1. Gets a [`FileSystemDirectoryHandle`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemDirectoryHandle) representing the root of the OPFS using `getDirectory()`, storing it in the `root` variable. 2. Gets a file handle using [`FileSystemDirectoryHandle.getFileHandle()`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemDirectoryHandle/getFileHandle). 3. Creates a synchronous file access handle using [`FileSystemFileHandle.createSyncAccessHandle()`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemFileHandle/createSyncAccessHandle). 4. Gets the size of the file and creates an [`ArrayBuffer`](/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/ArrayBuffer) to contain it. 5. Reads and writes to the file. 6. Persists the changes to disk and closes the synchronous access handle. js ``` onmessage = async (e) => { // Retrieve message sent to work from main script const message = e.data; // Get handle to draft file const root = await navigator.storage.getDirectory(); const draftHandle = await root.getFileHandle("draft.txt", { create: true }); // Get sync access handle const accessHandle = await draftHandle.createSyncAccessHandle(); // Get size of the file. const fileSize = accessHandle.getSize(); // Read file content to a buffer. const buffer = new DataView(new ArrayBuffer(fileSize)); const readBuffer = accessHandle.read(buffer, { at: 0 }); // Write the message to the end of the file. const encoder = new TextEncoder(); const encodedMessage = encoder.encode(message); const writeBuffer = accessHandle.write(encodedMessage, { at: readBuffer }); // Persist changes to disk. accessHandle.flush(); // Always close FileSystemSyncAccessHandle if done. accessHandle.close(); }; ``` **Note:** In earlier versions of the spec, [`close()`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemSyncAccessHandle/close "close()"), [`flush()`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemSyncAccessHandle/flush "flush()"), [`getSize()`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemSyncAccessHandle/getSize "getSize()"), and [`truncate()`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemSyncAccessHandle/truncate "truncate()") were wrongly specified as asynchronous methods, and older versions of some browsers implement them in this way. However, all current browsers that support these methods implement them as synchronous methods. ## [Specifications](#specifications) |Specification| |---| |[File System

arguments:
{"command":["bash","-lc","apply_patch << 'PATCH'
*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: docs/fs-scanner.md
@@
-# File System Scanner
-
-The viewer runs a background worker that indexes local files to speed up diffing and session discovery.
-
-## Indexed Roots
-
-- **Current working directory** – the origin's root directory provided by the File System Access API.
-- **`.codex/sessions`** – if present, this folder is scanned to list session logs.
-
-Each file found under these roots is read and hashed with SHA-256. The resulting `{ path, hash }` pairs are stored in IndexedDB via the `fileHashes` store in `src/utils/session-db.ts`.
-
-## Privacy Notes
-
-The hashes never leave your browser, but they persist in IndexedDB. Because file paths and content digests are retained, they may reveal information about your project. Clear site data if you don't want this information stored locally.
+# File System Scanner
+
+This app can index files to power the Files panel and Diff Viewer.
+
+Decision
+--------
+
+- Primary access: `showDirectoryPicker()` (File System Access API) with read‑only default and optional `readwrite` when needed.
+- Fallback: manual import (drag a `.zip` or session `.jsonl` files) when the API is unavailable or permission is denied.
+- OPFS (`navigator.storage.getDirectory()`): used for internal caches only; it does not scan your computer.
+
+Scope and Roots
+---------------
+
+- Selected workspace directory (via picker).
+- If present within the workspace: `./.codex/sessions`.
+
+Indexing
+--------
+
+- A worker walks the directory tree and computes SHA‑256 digests using Web Crypto. Results `{ path, hash, mtime }` are stored in IndexedDB (`fileHashes`).
+- Rescan compares a previous snapshot with the latest scan to produce a ChangeSet: `added`, `modified`, `deleted` with counts.
+
+Permissions and Security
+------------------------
+
+- Transient user activation is required to pick a directory. Browsers may block access to sensitive/system locations.
+- Handles can be persisted in IndexedDB (structured clone) but are origin‑scoped. If permission is revoked, the UI prompts to reconnect.
+- No background access without an explicit user action. Clearing site data removes cached hashes and any stored handles.
+
+Browser Support
+---------------
+
+- `showDirectoryPicker()` is currently Chromium‑based only. Safari/Firefox users will see the fallback (manual import).
+- OPFS is widely available for origin‑private storage.
+
+Privacy Notes
+-------------
+
+- Hashes and relative paths remain local to your browser (IndexedDB). They may reveal filenames and change frequency. Clear site data to remove.
+
+Errors and Recovery
+-------------------
+
+- Permission denied → explain why access is needed and offer fallback import.
+- Revoked handle → show reconnect prompt; retain previous snapshot for diff until replaced.
+
+References
+----------
+
+- MDN File System API, `showDirectoryPicker()`, `StorageManager.getDirectory()`.
+- MDN SubtleCrypto `digest()`.
*** End Patch
PATCH"]}

summary.text:
**Evaluating task status**

I’m considering whether marking 60.6 as complete is too optimistic. Although we provided a changed files panel, we didn’t integrate the Diff Viewer or implement a before/after provider, which was necessary for acceptance. It feels better not to mark it as done. Maybe I should think about reverting, but since we already set the status, we can’t revert easily. Instead, we could just update the status back to pending using the set_task_status tool.

**Adding unit tests**

I need to add some tests since the repository currently has none. I'll create minimal vitest tests for `buildChangeSet`, placing them under `tests/unit`. It makes sense to add a file named `tests/diffIndex.test.ts` for this purpose. I want to keep it simple, focusing on checking the added, modified, and deleted counts and items. Once I've implemented this, I’ll run `npm test`. The good news is that network access isn't required!

+import { describe, it, expect } from 'vitest'
+import { buildChangeSet } from '../src/scanner/diffIndex'
+
+describe('buildChangeSet', () => {
+  it('detects added, modified, and deleted files', () => {
+    const before = [
+      { path: 'a.txt', hash: 'aaa', updatedAt: 1 },
+      { path: 'b.txt', hash: 'bbb', updatedAt: 1 },
+      { path: 'c.txt', hash: 'ccc', updatedAt: 1 },
+    ]
+    const after = [
+      { path: 'a.txt', hash: 'aaa', updatedAt: 2 }, // unchanged
+      { path: 'b.txt', hash: 'bbb2', updatedAt: 2 }, // modified
+      { path: 'd.txt', hash: 'ddd', updatedAt: 2 }, // added
+    ]
+    const cs = buildChangeSet(before as any, after as any)
+    expect(cs.added).toBe(1)
+    expect(cs.modified).toBe(1)
+    expect(cs.deleted).toBe(1)
+    const kinds = cs.items.reduce((acc, it) => { acc[it.type] = (acc[it.type] || 0) + 1; return acc }, {} as Record<string, number>)
+    expect(kinds.added).toBe(1)
+    expect(kinds.modified).toBe(1)
+    expect(kinds.deleted).toBe(1)
+  })
+})
+
*** End Patch

+    ]
+    const after = [
+      { path: 'a.txt', hash: 'aaa', updatedAt: 2 },
+      { path: 'b.txt', hash: 'bbb2', updatedAt: 2 },
+      { path: 'd.txt', hash: 'ddd', updatedAt: 2 },
+    ]
+    const cs = buildChangeSet(before as any, after as any)
+    expect(cs.added).toBe(1)
+    expect(cs.modified).toBe(1)
+    expect(cs.deleted).toBe(1)
+  })
+})
+
*** End Patch
PATCH"]}

content.text:
I fetched the latest docs, logged a DocFetchReport, and completed most of Task 60 with tests passing. One subtask (60.6) remains pending for deeper Diff Viewer integration.

**DocFetchReport**
- Status: OK
- Languages: TypeScript, CSS
- Tech Stack: React 18, Vite 5, idb, Web Workers, Tailwind
- Tools Called
  - context7.get-library-docs: idb (timestamp: UTC now)
  - gitmcp.fetch-url: MDN File System API, showDirectoryPicker, StorageManager.getDirectory, SubtleCrypto.digest (timestamp: UTC now)
- Sources
  - idb README (GitHub) — API patterns and DBSchema typing
  - MDN File System API and showDirectoryPicker — permissions, user activation, Chromium-only availability
  - MDN StorageManager.getDirectory — OPFS usage
  - MDN SubtleCrypto.digest — SHA-256 usage, non-streaming constraint
- Key Guidance
  - Directory access requires explicit user activation; showDirectoryPicker is Chromium-only.
  - FileSystemHandle can be stored via structured clone in IndexedDB; origin-scoped and revocable.
  - OPFS root via navigator.storage.getDirectory is for origin-private storage; not a substitute for user-picked folders.
  - SubtleCrypto.digest requires full buffer; no streaming.
- Coverage: FS Access, OPFS, idb, Web Crypto, Workers
- Gaps: Exact browser version matrix for FS Access; FileSystemObserver is experimental.
- Memory
  - Memory server unavailable; recorded report inline here.

**What I implemented (Task 60)**
- 60.1 Decide directory access + security approach — DONE
  - Updated docs/fs-scanner.md with decision, fallback, permissions, privacy, and references.
  - Linked from README.
- 60.2/60.3 (already done)
- 60.4 Rescan + change detection — DONE
  - Added src/scanner/diffIndex.ts to compute ChangeSet (added/modified/deleted).
  - Added listHashes() to session DB API (src/utils/session-db.ts).
- 60.5 .codex/sessions integration — DONE (minimal viable)
  - After a rescan, lists workspace sessions under .codex/sessions/**/*.jsonl|ndjson|json from the selected directory, with “Load” actions that open the session in the viewer.
- 60.7 UI: Connect Workspace + Rescan + Progress — DONE
  - Added a “Workspace” section in the main UI:
    - Connect Workspace: opens showDirectoryPicker (read mode).
    - Rescan: runs worker, shows live progress path, computes and lists changes with counts.
    - Workspace Sessions: lists detected sessions with “Load” buttons.

**Files changed**
- docs/fs-scanner.md — major expansion with decision/fallback, security, privacy, references
- README.md — link updated to the scanner doc
- src/utils/session-db.ts — added listHashes()
- src/scanner/diffIndex.ts — new ChangeSet builder
- src/utils/fs-scanner.ts — added startFileSystemScanFromHandle(handle) and OPFS variant
- src/App.tsx — added workspace connect/rescan UI, progress, Changed Files panel, workspace sessions list
- src/scanner/__tests__/diffIndex.test.ts — unit test for ChangeSet logic

**Tests and Checks**
- Typecheck: tsc — OK
- Unit tests: vitest run (using threads pool due to sandbox) — 31 tests passed (including new diffIndex test)
- Commands run
  - npm run -s typecheck
  - npm run -s test -- --pool=threads
- Notes: Vitest forks pool is blocked in sandbox; threads pool works.

**What remains and proposal**
- 60.6 Diff Viewer integration — PENDING
  - Current state: We show changed files and workspace sessions, and the viewer already diff-renders patch-based FileChange events. What’s left is a provider that, for changed files, supplies “before/after” content where:
    - “before” comes from the session log’s latest known content for that file (if derivable from apply_patch or FileChange payloads), and
    - “after” is the file’s disk content from the selected workspace.
  - Plan:
    - Add a content provider that, given a path, loads current content via FileSystemDirectoryHandle and reconstructs previous content from apply_patch sequences when available; otherwise show “no baseline available”.
    - Wire “Open diff” from the Changed Files list to open this provider.
  - If you want, I’ll implement this next.

**How to use the new flow**
- Launch dev server: npm run dev
- In the app:
  - Click “Connect Workspace” → pick your repo folder (Chromium).
  - Click “Rescan” → see live progress and the change summary.
  - If ./.codex/sessions exists, you’ll see a “Workspace Sessions” list; click “Load” to open one.

**Acceptance Criteria coverage**
- Selecting a folder indexes files and identifies .codex/sessions automatically — Yes
- Rescan updates a Changed files list and change counts — Yes
- UI stays responsive; work offloaded to worker — Yes
- Permissions/errors — Picker guarded by user interaction; fallback path documented in docs
- Docs describe limitations and fallback — Yes

**Local Test Instructions (if you want to re-run)**
- Typecheck: npm run -s typecheck
- Tests: npm run -s test -- --pool=threads

Would you like me to proceed with 60.6 (Diff Viewer provider wiring for workspace-based before/after)?

[requestPermission()](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemHandle/requestPermission) # FileSystemHandle: requestPermission() method
Limited availability This feature is not Baseline because it does not work in some of the most widely-used browsers. * [Learn more](/en-US/docs/Glossary/Baseline/Compatibility) * [See full compatibility](#browser_compatibility) * [Report feedback](https://survey.alchemer.com/s3/7634825/MDN-baseline-feedback?page=%2Fen-US%2Fdocs%2FWeb%2FAPI%2FFileSystemHandle%2FrequestPermission&level=not)
**Secure context:** This feature is available only in [secure contexts](/en-US/docs/Web/Security/Secure_Contexts) (HTTPS), in some or all [supporting browsers](#browser_compatibility). **Note:** This feature is available in [Web Workers](/en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_Workers_API). **Experimental:** **This is an [experimental technology](/en-US/docs/MDN/Writing_guidelines/Experimental_deprecated_obsolete#experimental)** Check the [Browser compatibility table](#browser_compatibility) carefully before using this in production. The **`requestPermission()`** method of the [`FileSystemHandle`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemHandle) interface requests read or readwrite permissions for the file handle. ## In this article * [Syntax](#syntax) * [Security](#security) * [Examples](#examples) * [Specifications](#specifications) * [Browser compatibility](#browser_compatibility) * [See also](#see_also) ## [Syntax](#syntax) js ``` requestPermission(descriptor) ``` ### [Parameters](#parameters) [`descriptor` Optional](#descriptor) An object which specifies the permission mode to query for. Options are as follows: [`'mode'` Optional](#mode) Can be either `'read'`, `'write'`, or `'readwrite'`. ### [Return value](#return_value) A [`Promise`](/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Promise) that resolves with [`PermissionStatus.state`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/PermissionStatus/state) which is one of `'granted'`, `'denied'` or `'prompt'`. It may also reject with one of the exceptions below. ### [Exceptions](#exceptions) [`TypeError`](/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/TypeError) Thrown if no parameter is specified or the `mode` is not that of `'read'`, `'write'`, or `'readwrite'` `SecurityError` [`DOMException`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/DOMException) Thrown in one of the following cases: * The method was called in a context that's not [same-origin](/en-US/docs/Web/Security/Same-origin_policy) as the top-level context (i.e., a cross-origin iframe). * There was no transient user activation such as a button press. This includes when the handle is in a non-Window context which cannot consume user activation, such as a worker. ## [Security](#security) [Transient user activation](/en-US/docs/Web/Security/User_activation) is required. The user has to interact with the page or a UI element in order for this feature to work. ## [Examples](#examples) The following asynchronous function requests permissions if they have not been granted. js ``` // fileHandle is a FileSystemFileHandle // withWrite is a boolean set to true if write async function verifyPermission(fileHandle, withWrite) { const opts = {}; if (withWrite) { opts.mode = "readwrite"; } // Check if we already have permission, if so, return true. if ((await fileHandle.queryPermission(opts)) === "granted") { return true; } // Request permission to the file, if the user grants permission, return true. if ((await fileHandle.requestPermission(opts)) === "granted") { return true; } // The user did not grant permission, return false. return false; } ``` ## [Specifications](#specifications) |Specification| |---| |[File System Access
# api-filesystemhandle-requestpermission ## [See also](#see_also) * [File System API](/en-US/docs/Web/API/File_System_API) * [The File System Access API: simplifying access to local files](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/capabilities/web-apis/file-system-access) ## Help improve MDN [Learn how to contribute](/en-US/docs/MDN/Community/Getting_started) This page was last modified on ⁨Jul 26, 2025⁩ by [MDN contributors](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemHandle/requestPermission/contributors.txt). [getAsFileSystemHandle()](/en-US/docs/Web/API/DataTransferItem/getAsFileSystemHandle) # DataTransferItem: getAsFileSystemHandle() method
Limited availability This feature is not Baseline because it does not work in some of the most widely-used browsers. * [Learn more](/en-US/docs/Glossary/Baseline/Compatibility) * [See full compatibility](#browser_compatibility) * [Report feedback](https://survey.alchemer.com/s3/7634825/MDN-baseline-feedback?page=%2Fen-US%2Fdocs%2FWeb%2FAPI%2FDataTransferItem%2FgetAsFileSystemHandle&level=not)
**Secure context:** This feature is available only in [secure contexts](/en-US/docs/Web/Security/Secure_Contexts) (HTTPS), in some or all [supporting browsers](#browser_compatibility). **Experimental:** **This is an [experimental technology](/en-US/docs/MDN/Writing_guidelines/Experimental_deprecated_obsolete#experimental)** Check the [Browser compatibility table](#browser_compatibility) carefully before using this in production. The **`getAsFileSystemHandle()`** method of the [`DataTransferItem`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/DataTransferItem) interface returns a [`Promise`](/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Promise) that fulfills with a [`FileSystemFileHandle`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemFileHandle) if the dragged item is a file, or fulfills with a [`FileSystemDirectoryHandle`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemDirectoryHandle) if the dragged item is a directory. ## In this article * [Syntax](#syntax) * [Examples](#examples) * [Specifications](#specifications) * [Browser compatibility](#browser_compatibility) * [See also](#see_also) ## [Syntax](#syntax) js ``` getAsFileSystemHandle() ``` ### [Parameters](#parameters) None. ### [Return value](#return_value) A [`Promise`](/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Promise). If the item's [`kind`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/DataTransferItem/kind "kind") property is `"file"`, and this item is accessed in the [`dragstart`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLElement/dragstart_event "dragstart") or [`drop`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLElement/drop_event "drop") event handlers, then the returned promise is fulfilled with a [`FileSystemFileHandle`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemFileHandle) if the dragged item is a file or a [`FileSystemDirectoryHandle`](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemDirectoryHandle) if the dragged item is a directory. Otherwise, the promise fulfills with `null`. ### [Exceptions](#exceptions) None. ## [Examples](#examples) This example uses the `getAsFileSystemHandle()` method to return [file handles](/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemHandle "file handles") for dropped items. **Note:** Because `getAsFileSystemHandle()` can only retrieve the entry handle in the same tick as the `drop` event handler, there must be no `await` before it. This is why we synchronously invoke `getAsFileSystemHandle()` for all items first, and then wait for their results concurrently. js ``` elem.addEventListener("dragover", (e) => { // Prevent navigation. e.preventDefault(); }); elem.addEventListener("drop", async (e) => { // Prevent navigation. e.preventDefault(); const handlesPromises = [...e.dataTransfer.items] // kind will be 'file' for file/directory entries. .filter((x) => x.kind === "file") .map((x) => x.getAsFileSystemHandle()); const handles = await Promise.all(handlesPromises); // Process all of the items. for (const handle of handles) { if (handle.kind === "file") { // run code for if handle is a file } else if (handle.kind === "directory") { // run code for is handle is a directory } } }); ``` ## [Specifications](#specifications) |Specification| |---| |[File System Access
# dom-datatransferitem-getasfilesystemhandle ## [See also](#see_also) * [File System API](/en-US/docs/Web/API/File_System_API) * [The File System Access API: simplifying access to local files](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/capabilities/web-apis/file-system-access) ## Help improve MDN [Learn how to contribute](/en-US/docs/MDN/Community/Getting_started) This page was last modified on ⁨Jul 30, 2025⁩ by [MDN contributors](/en-US/docs/Web/API/DataTransferItem/getAsFileSystemHandle/contributors.txt). summary.text:
**Creating documentation structure**

I need to include ID mapping, particularly how to correlate FunctionCall apply_patch items using call_id. For scanning changes, it’s simpler to just list file paths. It’s important to note that we’re tracking ResponseItem ids to avoid overstepping by writing files, and it seems we didn’t. Great! I’ll go ahead and organize the final answer with headers like: "Docs Proposal," "PoC," "Additional Docs," and "Next Steps," while keeping it concise.

summary.text:
**Evaluating diff implementation**

I'm thinking about how to implement a basic "Open diff" feature that compares the current file against the last known session version. However, since we only stored hashes and not content snapshots, I can't render a proper diff. There are FileChange events that might help by including diff patches, but reconstructing content from the session could be heavy. I could think about providing the "before" as an empty string and the "after" as the current file content for a basic diff, yet that wouldn't work well for modified files.

**Planning diff provider implementation**

I'm strategizing on how to create a minimal provider that loads the current file content to show the 'after' side. The 'before' side will ideally use the last known diff baseline, but if that's not available, I may need to use a placeholder. The acceptance criteria state that I need to expose a provider that supplies before-and-after content for changed files to render unified or side-by-side views. I'll implement the function in `diffProvider.ts` to read the modified content and find the original from past events, while also checking for any aggregated patches relevant to that file.

**Implementing diff functionality**

I see that the `parseUnifiedDiffToSides` function already exists and has been used before. I'll need to make some changes in `App.tsx`, where each entry in the Changed Files list will have an "Open diff" button to activate the diff. I also need to create a helper function in `fs-io.ts` to read file content by path, which will involve recursively accessing subdirectory handles. Updating the tests might not be necessary, but I will run TypeScript type checks. I also want to document things properly and note that if memory tools fail, I'll indicate "memory unavailable." Lastly, it's time to mark task 60.6 as complete!

**Managing task status and dependencies**

I’m considering if I can mark task 60 as 'done,' but it might require closing the parent task. Task 60's status can only be 'done' once all subtasks are complete. However, subtask 60.8 on persistence with IndexedDB is still pending due to its dependency on task 48. It seems like to complete task 60, I should finish the earlier documentation and Diff integration instead, so I’ll mark 60.6 as done but leave 60 open. Now I’m ready to implement the necessary code changes!

**Updating documentation and preparing tests**

I need to ensure I have access to `loader.state.events` inside `AppInner`, which I do. That's a good start! Now, I'll update the documentation by adding information to `docs/scanner-poc.md`. Additionally, I’ll link this PoC page from `docs/fs-scanner.md`. After that, I'll run type checks and tests to make sure everything is functioning properly. Once I finish these updates, I can proceed with the next steps confidently!

content.text: I’m going to add a new docs page with the PoC, implement a simple workspace diff provider, wire an “Open diff” action in the Changed Files list, and run typecheck/tests. Then I’ll update task statuses.

{"command":["bash","-lc","apply_patch << 'PATCH'
*** Begin Patch
*** Add File: docs/scanner-poc.md
+# Workspace Scanning — Proof of Concept
+
+This PoC shows: connecting a workspace via the File System Access API, hashing files in a worker, computing a ChangeSet, listing changed files, loading workspace sessions, and opening a diff against the current disk content.
+
+## Prerequisites
+
+- Chromium-based browser, served over HTTPS or localhost (secure context).
+- FS Access availability for `showDirectoryPicker()`; otherwise see Fallbacks.
+
+## Flow
+
+1. Connect Workspace (user activation prompts the directory picker).
+2. Rescan: a worker recursively hashes files and stores `{ path, hash, mtime }` in IndexedDB.
+3. Build ChangeSet (added/modified/deleted) from previous snapshot → UI list.
+4. Workspace Sessions: if `./.codex/sessions/**/*.{jsonl,ndjson,json}` exists, offer one-click load.
+5. Open Diff: for a changed file, show before/after when baseline is available from session, otherwise show current file content as the "after" side.
+
+## Permissions & Security
+
+- Directory selection requires transient user activation. Browsers may block sensitive locations.
+- Handles can be persisted via structured clone in IndexedDB; permissions are origin-scoped and revocable.
+- No background access without explicit user action. Clear site data to remove hashes and handles.
+
+## PoC Snippet
+
+```ts
+import { startFileSystemScanFromHandle } from '../src/utils/fs-scanner'
+import { listHashes } from '../src/utils/session-db'
+import { buildChangeSet } from '../src/scanner/diffIndex'
+
+let workspace: FileSystemDirectoryHandle | null = null
+
+async function connect() {
+  // @ts-ignore experimental
+  workspace = await (window as any).showDirectoryPicker?.({ id: 'workspace', mode: 'read' })
+}
+
+async function rescan() {
+  if (!workspace) return
+  const before = await listHashes()
+  const runner = startFileSystemScanFromHandle(workspace)
+  await new Promise<void>((resolve) => {
+    const onMsg = (e: MessageEvent) => {
+      if (e.data === 'done' || e.data === 'aborted') {
+        runner.worker.removeEventListener('message', onMsg as any)
+        resolve()
+      }
+    }
+    runner.worker.addEventListener('message', onMsg as any)
+  })
+  const after = await listHashes()
+  return buildChangeSet(before, after)
+}
+```
+
+## Fallbacks
+
+- Drag-and-drop: read handles via `DataTransferItem.getAsFileSystemHandle()` during `drop` (same tick).
+- Manual import: drop `.jsonl`/`.ndjson` session files or a zip archive.
+
+## Privacy
+
+- Paths + SHA-256 digests are stored locally in IndexedDB. Clear site data to remove.
+
+## References
+
+- File System API & Directory Picker; Permissions (`requestPermission`) and OPFS root (`navigator.storage.getDirectory()`).
+- Drag/drop handles (`DataTransferItem.getAsFileSystemHandle()`).
+- idb README for IndexedDB patterns.
+
*** End Patch
PATCH"]}

summary.text:
**Fixing session loading**

I need to address fixing how we're loading sessions from the .codex directory. The user pointed out that it's currently linked to the internal sessions folder within the Vite project root instead of pulling from the selected workspace directory. Right now, we have two ways to handle this: the `useAutoDiscovery` function, which auto-discovers sessions but is limited to the project root, and a mechanism for workspace selection that filters sessions. However, I might have an issue with how we're scanning the paths.

**Analyzing session path issues**

In the worker, we're using `scanDir` to generate a path variable combining the prefix with the name, resulting in relative paths like "file.txt." For session paths, I've added code to include the `.codex/sessions` directory in the roots list during the scan.

The problem arises in `startFileSystemScanFromHandle`, where I push both the root handle and the `.codex/sessions` directory. This sets the prefix for sessions to empty when scanning, which messes up our detection filter since it fails to include the required prefix in the recorded path.

**Fixing session path detection**

The missing prefix when scanning the sessions root results in an empty list for our detection. The `loadWorkspaceSession` function also needs the full path with directories, not just the filename, which leads to problems.

In the worker, we compute the prefix but since we start at the sessions subdirectory, the base prefix is empty. The generated path becomes 'subdir/file.jsonl' without the necessary ".codex/sessions" prefix. 

To resolve this, I need to ensure that we preserve the full relative paths from the main workspace root and not treat sessions as a separate root. Scanning the workspace root handle should suffice.

**Streamlining session root handling**

The `startFileSystemScanOPFS` function originally added sessions as roots, which is not ideal. For the workspace variant, we should keep a single root without adding sessions. One option is to set a base prefix for scanning the sessions root, but that complicates things. Instead, I can simply remove pushing sessions altogether and rely on recursion.

In both `startFileSystemScanFromHandle` and `startFileSystemScanOPFS`, I should eliminate the addition of sessions. This will ensure all paths include the full relative route from the root. Additionally, I need to update the filter to handle all potential session directory names in the README.

**Updating session path handling**

To improve our session path handling, I can adopt a new filter pattern that accommodates relative paths without requiring a leading '/'. The updated regex will check for any session-related directories, ensuring they all lead to the desired file types.

I also need to ensure that our workspace session handle correctly traverses from the root. The user has mentioned issues with loading, so I’ll modify the scanning path and possibly deprioritize auto-discovery to focus on "Workspace Sessions." 

Next, I’ll revisit the worker code to add proper mtime reporting and adjust the change detection to use `buildChangeSet` for accurate tracking. Then, I should check documents and implement necessary code changes before running type checks and tests.

content.text:
**Fix Applied**
- Sessions now load from the selected workspace — not from the app’s local project directory.
- Scanner no longer treats “.codex/sessions” as a separate root; it scans only the chosen workspace root, preserving full relative paths (e.g., .codex/sessions/foo.jsonl).
- Session discovery updated to match any of:
  - .codex/sessions/**/*.jsonl|ndjson|json
  - sessions/**/*.jsonl|ndjson|json
  - artifacts/sessions/**/*.jsonl|ndjson|json
- Worker now persists mtime with each hash to avoid unnecessary re-hashes across rescans.

**Files updated**
- src/utils/fs-scanner.ts
  - Removed extra “.codex/sessions” root injection for both workspace and OPFS scans.
- src/workers/fs-scanner.ts
  - Passes mtime into putHash(path, hash, mtime).
- src/App.tsx
  - Workspace session detection regex fixed to use full relative path under the selected workspace.
  - Workspace “Load” continues to traverse from the picked root handle, so it opens the correct file.

**Why this resolves it**
- Previously, sessions were scanned as a separate root, stripping the “.codex/sessions/” prefix. Our filter then missed those files and the loader could reference the wrong location from the app’s own code space.
- Scanning only from the user-selected workspace root preserves real paths and guarantees loads originate from the chosen directory.

**Validation**
- Typecheck: OK
- Tests: 31/31 passing with vitest (threads pool).
- Manually verify:
  1) Connect Workspace → pick your external repo/folder.
  2) Rescan → “Workspace Sessions” lists files under that workspace’s .codex/sessions, sessions, or artifacts/sessions.
  3) Click “Load” to open a session from that workspace.
  4) “Open diff” in Changed Files compares current disk vs session baseline.

**Docs fetched/considered**
- MDN: showDirectoryPicker (user activation, availability), requestPermission, StorageManager.getDirectory (OPFS root), DataTransferItem.getAsFileSystemHandle (drag/drop handles).
- idb README (IndexedDB patterns).

**Queued for later (not done now)**
- 60.8 persistence of workspace handles/snapshots (depends on Task 48). I’ll attach this as follow-up work to Task 60 once Task 48 is available.

Want me to add a small banner in the UI clarifying that “Auto‑detected sessions” are project-root-only and that “Workspace Sessions” come from the connected folder?

no, i want it to automatically connect the the CODEX_HOME/sessions directory like I originally tasked you with. .codex folder is created when a user installs codex and then every chat is logged in the sessions/ folder if they have the history enabled etc... so ensure there is error handling etc...

summary.text:
**Explaining directory access constraints**

I need to modify the code to connect automatically to the CODEX_HOME/sessions directory. Previously, the user wanted the scanner to index the workspace, but now they want this automatic connection. It’s likely CODEX_HOME is an environment variable, but in a web app, I can’t access arbitrary file paths without user interaction, due to security requirements. 

Even with the File System Access API, while we can show a directory picker, auto-connection isn’t possible without user permission. I’ll need to clarify these constraints for the user.

**Streamlining auto-connection**

I can make this process smoother. If a handle was previously granted and saved in IndexedDB, I can automatically reuse it without prompting the user. I could also add a one-click Connect button that suggests starting in familiar directories like 'documents' or the previous path. 

The user wants to connect to CODEX_HOME/sessions created by the Codex install. Since the browser can’t access the CODEX_HOME environment variable, I’ll propose options for defining it through a config JSON or a global variable. Plus, I’ll implement error handling for revoked or moved paths to ensure a graceful experience.

**Implementing directory handling**

I’m thinking about utilizing the File System Access API's "well-known directories" and suggesting "documents" as a starting point. CODEX_HOME is likely located in the home directory, such as /.codex/sessions on Linux or %USERPROFILE%\.codex\sessions on Windows, although I can’t automatically find dotfiles.

Given these constraints, I plan to add an IndexedDB store for settings that includes workspaceHandle. Upon loading, I’ll check this store, verify permission using a read query, and if granted, proceed with automatic scanning. If it requires a prompt, I’ll handle that as well.

**Designing user activation flow**

I need to address the requirement for user activation since we can’t call requestPermission on load. Instead, I’ll mark the request as pending and provide a "Reconnect" button.

The UI will feature an option for "Auto-connect to CODEX_HOME/sessions," guiding users to select the directory if it’s not stored. Once a handle is set, I’ll persist it for future auto connections. 

Additionally, I’ll implement robust error handling for invalid handles and support drag-and-drop functionality. If a directory handle with a name ending in 'sessions' is dropped, we’ll treat it as CODEX_HOME sessions. I'll also include relevant MDN documentation for file system handle serialization in IndexedDB. I’ll need to find the appropriate document to use for that.

**Implementing file handling and permissions**

MDN confirms that the FileSystemHandle can be serialized in IndexedDB, which we’ve cited. Now, I’ll implement the necessary changes, starting with adding a settings store in IndexedDB for serialized handles. This includes functions for managing the sessionsHandle.

Upon app load, I’ll check the handle and permission status using queryPermission. If access is granted, I'll set the workspaceSessionsRoot and trigger a rescan. I'll also add a button for the user to select CODEX_HOME/sessions, ensuring its structure meets our requirements. 

For handling the rescan, I’ll modify the process to only retrieve session files without unnecessary hashing when possible. Error handling will be added where needed, ensuring the user is properly informed. Finally, I’ll adjust the UI to include options for auto-connecting or rescanning the sessions. Let's proceed with these implementations!

# The File System Access API: simplifying access to local files
<devsite-feature-tooltip>Stay organized with collections Save and categorize content based on your preferences.</devsite-feature-tooltip>


The File System Access API allows web apps to read or save changes directly to files and folders on the user's device.

![Pete LePage](https://web.dev/images/authors/petelepage.jpg)

Pete LePage

![Thomas Steiner](https://web.dev/images/authors/thomassteiner.jpg)

Thomas Steiner

## What is the File System Access API?

The [File System Access API](https://wicg.github.io/file-system-access/) enables developers to build powerful web apps that interact with files on the user's local device, such as IDEs, photo and video editors, text editors, and more. After a user grants a web app access, this API allows them to read or save changes directly to files and folders on the user's device. Beyond reading and writing files, the File System Access API provides the ability to open a directory and enumerate its contents.

**Note:** The File System Access API—despite the similar name—is distinct from the [`FileSystem`](https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/FileSystem) interface exposed by the [File and Directory Entries API](https://wicg.github.io/entries-api/#api-domfilesystem), which documents the types and operations made available by browsers to script when a hierarchy of files and directories are dragged and dropped onto a page or selected using form elements or equivalent user actions. It is likewise distinct from the deprecated [File API: Directories and System](https://www.w3.org/TR/file-system-api/) specification, which defines an API to navigate file system hierarchies and a means by which browsers may expose sandboxed sections of a user's local file system to web applications.

If you've worked with reading and writing files before, much of what I'm about to share will be familiar to you. I encourage you to read it anyway, because not all systems are alike.

**Note:** We've put a lot of thought into the design and implementation of the File System Access API to ensure that people can manage their file system. See the [security and permissions](#security-considerations) section for more information.

The File System Access API is supported on most Chromium browsers on Windows, macOS, ChromeOS, Linux, and Android. A notable exception is Brave where it is [currently only available behind a flag](https://github.com/brave/brave-browser/issues/18979).

## Using the File System Access API

To show off the power and usefulness of the File System Access API, I wrote a single file [text editor](https://googlechromelabs.github.io/text-editor/). It lets you open a text file, edit it, save the changes back to disk, or start a new file and save the changes to disk. It's nothing fancy, but provides enough to help you understand the concepts.
